questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a component of the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Duration of illness is not a part of the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis. The epidemiological triad includes host, agent and environment: • Host factors: Age, sex, religion, race, genetic profile, immune system • Agent factors: • Biological - bacteria, viruses • Chemical - poisons, alcohol, smoke • Physical - trauma, fire, radiation • Nutrition - lack/excess • Environmental factors: • Temperature, humidity, altitude • Water, milk, food • Radiation, pollution, noise • Crowding, housing, neighborhood 49 
Sold by @itachibot Hence, a malnourished child (host), Mycobacterium tuberculosis (agent) and overcrowding 
(environment) form the epidemiological triad for tuberculosis.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is the most logical sequence?
questions.explanation:
Disease  Impairment  Disability  Handicap is the most logical sequence among the given 
options. Disease is a state of physiological/psychological dysfunction. Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function. Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment. Handicap is the disadvantage due to disability that limits fulfilment of a role that is normal. 50 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A salesman met with an unfortunate accident that led to him eventually losing his left foot. 
He has been unable to walk after this incident and so been rendered unemployed. Match the 
following examples with the corresponding events explaining the concept of disability.
questions.explanation:
The correctly matched events relating to the given example are as follows: The WHO definition of impairment is "any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological or 
anatomical structure or function". E.g., loss of a foot. An initial impairment may cause a 
secondary impairment as well. The WHO defines disability as ''any restriction or lack of ability to perform an activity in the 
manner or within the range considered normal for a human being". Because of impairment, the 
affected person may be unable to carry out certain activities and hence the person is considered 
disabled. According to the WHO, a handicap is "a disadvantage for a given individual, resulting from an 
impairment or a disability, that limits or prevents the fulfilment of a role that is normal 
(depending on age, sex, and social and cultural factors) for that individual". The disadvantages 
experienced by a person as a result of disability makes them handicapped. Event

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is most appropriate about the web of disease causation?

options.a: It implies that individual factors in the web have equal weightage
options.b: It implies that all the chains of causation must be controlled to prevent disease
options.c: It is mostly applicable for acute and rare diseases
options.d: It suggests ways of interrupting the disease occurrence

questions.explanation:
The web of causation for a disease suggests a number of ways to interrupt the disease 
occurrence/progression. This model was suggested by MacMahon and Pugh in their book ‘Epidemiologic Principles and 
Methods’. Web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with 
each other. This model is ideally suited in the study of chronic disease. The web of causation does 
not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are 
removed. Sometimes removal of one significant link is sufficient to control the disease. In a multifactorial event, individual factors are by no means of equal weightage. The importance 
of each factor is expressed in terms of relative risk.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is not true regarding the pathogenesis period of a disease?

options.b: Recovery is seen in this period
options.c: Entry of causative agent is seen

questions.explanation:
Primary prevention is not possible in the pathogenesis period of a disease. It can only be done in 
the period of pre-pathogenesis. The two phases in the natural history of a disease include: • Period of pre-pathogenesis: It is before the onset of disease in humans. The disease agent has 
not entered the host, but the factors favouring the disease already exist. Primary 
prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period. • Period of pathogenesis: It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death or disability. 
Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) 
are applicable in this period. It isn't always characterised by the presence of disease symptoms as 
it also includes subclinical cases.

questions.question:
Question 6: In the iceberg phenomenon of disease, which of the following does not represent the 
submerged portion of the iceberg?
questions.explanation:
Epidemiologically, the iceberg phenomenon of disease, diagnosed cases are represented by the 
floating tip of the iceberg. The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The water surface is the 
line of demarcation between the apparent and inapparent infections. The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, 
latent, and undiagnosed cases. Screening is done to identify these cases. The iceberg phenomenon of disease is depicted in the image below. 52

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following diseases shows the iceberg phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Rubella shows the iceberg phenomenon of disease. The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and 
measles. Iceberg phenomenon is shown by: • Polio • Influenza • Rubella • Mumps • Japanese Encephalitis • Diphtheria • Hepatitis A and B • Tuberculosis • Diabetes • Malnutrition • Hypertension Note: If a disease has more number of subclinical infections, it shows the iceberg phenomenon of 
disease depicted in the image below. 53

questions.question: Question 8: What is the term used to describe the interruption in the transmission of a disease?
questions.explanation:
Interruption in the transmission of a disease is called elimination. It is a step towards eradication. Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very 
low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued 
measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required. Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious 
disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required. Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution 
of disease and ill health. Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at 
decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease.

questions.question: Question 9: Among the following options, which aids the most in disease elimination?
questions.explanation:
Herd immunity aids the most in disease elimination. Herd immunity achieved, especially through immunization, goes a long way in helping the 
elimination of diseases. When a high level of herd immunity is maintained, the susceptible 
population is reduced to a small proportion, thereby eliminating the disease. The purpose of isolation is to protect the community by preventing the transfer of infection from 
the reservoir to the possible susceptible hosts. Quarantine refers to restrictions on the healthy 
contacts of an infectious disease. 54 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: While collecting surveillance data for disease X, you find that the incidence of the disease is 
zero in your region. Which of the following statements best describes this scenario?

options.a: Disease is eliminated from the region.
options.b: Disease is well controlled in the region.
options.c: Disease is eradicated from the region.
options.d: Disease shows iceberg phenomenon in the region.

questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, as the disease has zero incidence, we can say the disease has been 
eliminated from the region. Elimination is a reduction in the number of new cases of an infectious disease to zero (or a very 
low defined target rate) in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts. Continued 
measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required. Eradication is a complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious 
disease through deliberate efforts. No further control measures are required. Control aims at decreasing the incidence, duration and transmission of the disease. It also aims at 
decreasing the physical and psychological complications of a disease. The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The submerged portion 
of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, latent, and undiagnosed 
cases. The clinical or diagnosed cases are represented by the floating tip of the iceberg and not the 
submerged portion. As disease incidence is zero here, there are no cases to form the iceberg.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is a silent epidemic?
questions.explanation:
Alzheimer’s disease is referred to as the silent epidemic of the century. Nearly 50 million people globally are living with this disease. Since it strikes so often, so 
arbitrarily, and with such little warning, many have dubbed it the silent epidemic.

questions.question:
Question 12: What is the analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status 
of a population called?
questions.explanation:
The analysis of routine measurements aimed at detecting changes in the health status or 
environment of a population is called monitoring. Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution 
of disease and ill health. Sentinel surveillance is a method of identifying the missing cases and thereby supplementing the 
notified cases. Systematic reviews involve a detailed plan with the goal of reducing bias by identifying, 
appraising, and synthesizing all relevant studies on a particular topic.

questions.question: Question 13: In which of the following does surveillance of disease not have a direct role?

options.c: Data on new and changing trends

questions.explanation:
Surveillance of a disease does not have a direct role in breaking the chain of transmission. Surveillance is the continuous scrutiny of factors that determine the occurrence and distribution 
of disease and ill health. 55 
Sold by @itachibot It helps in health planning and provides information about public health disasters including data 
on new and changing trends of disease. Surveillance requires professional analysis and sophisticated judgment of data, leading to 
recommendations for control activities.

questions.question: Question 14: Measures in sentinel surveillance do not aim at identifying:
questions.explanation:
Sentinel surveillance does not include identifying cases free of disability. Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases, in addition to the already existing and 
new cases. It is used for supplementing routine notifications.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is public health surveillance preferentially aimed at?
questions.explanation:
Public health surveillance is preferentially aimed at health planning. Public health surveillance provides important feedback on the health status of the population, 
about planning control and prevention activities, and also for public health disasters.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is included under primordial prevention of coronary artery disease?
questions.explanation:
Adoption of a healthy lifestyle from childhood would fall under the category of primordial 
prevention of coronary artery disease. Primordial prevention is preventing the emergence of risk factors among population groups in 
which these risk factors have not yet appeared. Most adult health problems (obesity, 
hypertension) have their early origins in childhood. It is in childhood that lifestyles are formed i.e. 
eating patterns, physical exercise, smoking, etc. In primordial prevention, efforts are made to discourage children from adopting harmful 
lifestyles. These lifestyle changes when made by adults are known as primary prevention.

questions.question: Question 17: What type of prevention is the prescriptive screening of a disease?
questions.explanation:
Prescriptive screening of a disease is an example of secondary prevention. Prescriptive screening of disease can lead to early diagnosis of disease. By early diagnosis, 
intervention can be made to prevent disability. Hence, it comes under secondary prevention.

questions.question: Question 18: What form of prevention is prospective screening?
questions.explanation:
56 
Sold by @itachibot Prospective screening is a type of primary prevention. Prospective screening is done on healthy individuals to screen for disease. It is done prior to the 
onset of the disease. E.g., screening donated blood for HIV before it is transfused. This type of 
prevention reduces the incidence of disease. Note: Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are screened for their own benefits. 
It is an early diagnosis of diseases existing in them. This is a form of secondary prevention. E.g., 
neonatal screening for hypothyroidism, pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.

questions.question:
Question 19: You advise a reproductive age woman to vaccinate against HPV. What is this type of 
prevention called?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of immunisation is an example of primary prevention. Primary prevention is an action taken before the onset of disease. This reduces the possibility of 
disease occurrence. Hence, immunization is a form of primary prevention, through specific 
protection. Examples of primary prevention include immunization, sanitation, solid and liquid waste 
management etc.

questions.question: Question 20: Who among the following is not a target for primary prevention?
questions.explanation:
Asymptomatic patients are the target population for secondary prevention but not for primary 
prevention. Primary prevention is implemented before the onset of the disease. Hence, all patients including 
asymptomatic ones are not included in the target group.

questions.question:
Question 21: As a part of the iodine deficiency control programme, you advocate the usage of iodized salt 
in hilly areas. What is this type of prevention an example of?
questions.explanation:
The usage of iodized salt in iodine-deficient areas like in hilly regions is an example of primary 
prevention as it provides specific protection.

questions.question:
Question 22: You are performing a routine pap smear on a 30-year-old woman in the gynecology OPD. 
What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.explanation:
Pap smear is a screening test for carcinoma cervix and is an example of secondary prevention. Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment are the components of secondary prevention. 
Some of the examples of secondary prevention are as follows: • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer • Mammography for early detection of breast cancer • Colonoscopies for early detection of colon cancer 57 
Sold by @itachibot • Blood Pressure Screening Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as 
dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures 
from a state of health.

questions.question: Question 23: What mode of prevention is disability prevention by appropriate treatment an example of?
questions.explanation:
Disability prevention by appropriate treatment is an example of secondary prevention. This is 
because disability has not occurred yet so correct treatment can stop it from developing. After the disability has set in, prevention of progression of disability from transitioning into a 
handicap is tertiary prevention. It is also called disability limitation.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following is an example of disability limitation?

options.b: Starting a patient on anti-tuberculous therapy

questions.explanation:
Prescribing spectacles for refractive error is an example of disability limitation which is a 
component of tertiary prevention. This mode of intervention is applicable when the patient 
presents late in the pathogenesis phase. The objective of this intervention is to prevent or halt the transition of the disease process from 
impairment to handicap. Option B: Starting a patient on anti-tuberculous therapy is secondary prevention as it is a part of 
treatment. Option C: Abstinence from smoking is a modification of the risk factor. Hence it is an example of 
primary prevention. Option D: Early fixation of fractures will prevent disability. Hence, it is an example of secondary 
prevention.

questions.question: Question 25: Which among the following diseases was eliminated in India in 2015?
questions.explanation:
Maternal and neonatal tetanus was eliminated from India in 2015, as certified by the WHO. Important years for India (declared disease-free): • Infective trachoma - 2017 • Yaws - 2016 • Maternal & neonatal tetanus - 2015 • Polio - 2014 • Guinea worm disease (dracunculiasis) - 2000 Worldwide eradication: 58

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following statements is false about ICD- 11?
questions.explanation:
The new ICD-11 has a new chapter on sexual health that contains gender incongruence, which was 
previously listed under mental health conditions in the ICD-10. The ICD 11 was released by the WHO in June 201› and was presented at the World Health 
Assembly in May 201š for adoption by the Member States. It has come into effect from 1 January 
2022. Its designations for antibiotic resistance align with the Global Antimicrobial Resistance 
Surveillance System (GLASS). It is given by the WHO and is revised every 10 years. New chapters added in ICD-11 are: • Traditional medicine • Sexual health: Gender incongruence has been moved from mental health to sexual health. • Gaming disorder has been added under Addictive disorders. • Immune system disorders, which will enable the better study of allergies. It has more detail on cancer, specifically different types of skin cancer, as well as on heart health 
and weight disorders compared to ICD-10. 59 
Sold by @itachibot Principles of Epidemiology
